title: How to Cook Cipollini Onions

steps.headline: Preheat the oven and place the rack in the center.
steps.description: To ensure that the oven is hot enough to roast the onions, set the temperature to 325°F (165°C) and allow it to fully heat. Make sure that the oven rack is the center position as well.

steps.headline: Melt the butter on the stove.
steps.description: Add 4 tablespoons (57 g) of unsalted butter to a large non-stick skillet. Heat the butter over medium until it melts completely, which should take about 3 minutes.

steps.headline: Toss the onions with the butter.
steps.description: Once the butter is melted, add 2 pounds (907 g) of cipollini onions that have been peeled and had their roots trimmed. Use a wooden spoon to stir the onions well so they're fully coated with the butter.

steps.headline: Season the onions with salt and pepper.
steps.description: When the onions are coated with the butter, add some kosher salt and freshly ground pepper to taste. Stir well to ensure that the onions are evenly seasoned.

steps.headline: Transfer the mixture to a roasting pan.
steps.description: After you've seasoned the onions, remove the skillet from the heat. Spoon the onions and melted butter into a roasting pan, making sure that they're evenly distributed and in a single layer.

steps.headline: Cook the onions until tender.
steps.description: Place the onions in the preheated oven. Allow the onions to roast until they tender and fully caramelized, which should take about half an hour. While the onions are roasting, toss them occasionally to ensure that they cook evenly.

steps.headline: Serve the onions immediately.
steps.description: When the onions are deeply caramelized, remove the pan from the oven. Transfer them to a platter and serve while they're still warm. Roasted cipollini onions are ideal side for any roasted meat main dish.

steps.headline: Heat the olive oil in a skillet.
steps.description: Add 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of olive oil to a large skillet. Allow the oil to heat on medium-high for 3 to 5 minutes, or until it begins to shimmer.

steps.headline: Add the onions and season with salt.
steps.description: When the oil is heated, mix 2 pounds (907 g) of cipollini onions that have been peeled and had their roots trimmed into the pan. Stir in some salt to taste to season the onions.

steps.headline: Sprinkle the onions with sugar and cook them for a minute.
steps.description: After you've seasoned the onions, scatter 1 tablespoon (12 ½ g) of sugar over them. Next, allow the onions to cook for 1 minute without stirring them.

steps.headline: Mix in the butter and cook the onions until they begin to caramelize.
steps.description: When the onions have cooked for a minute, add 3 tablespoons (43 g) of butter to the pan and stir it in to help it melt. Continue cooking the onions until they begin to develop a deep caramelization, which should take about 5 to 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Turn the onions over and mix in the thyme and sherry.
steps.description: When the onions are starting to caramelize, use a spatula to carefully turn them over. Cook them for another minute, and then add ¼ cup (10 g) of fresh thyme leaves and ⅓ cup (79 g) of sherry to the pan. Stir well to ensure that the ingredients are fully mixed.

steps.headline: Allow the onions to cook for another 10 minutes.
steps.description: Once the thyme and sherry are mixed into the pan, let the onions cook for 10 more minutes. You'll know that they're done when they are tender and deeply caramelized all over.

steps.headline: Remove the onions from the heat and stir in the cream.
steps.description: When the onions are finished sauteing, take the pan off the stove. Add ¼ cup (59 ml) of heavy cream to the pan, and mix it in well. If you like, you can also mix ¼ cup (30 g) of Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese into the pan.

steps.headline: Season the onions and serve immediately.
steps.description: Once the cream is mixed into the onions, add as much salt and pepper to taste as you'd like. Transfer the onions to a dish and serve while they're still hot. Sautéed Cipollini onions pair well with roasted turkey.

steps.headline: Soak some wooden skewers in water.
steps.description: To grill the onions, you'll need 2 to 4 wooden skewers, depending on how long they are. Place the skewers in a shallow dish and cover them with water. Let them soak for 30 minutes so they won't burn on the grill.

steps.headline: Toss the onions, basil, salt, and oil together.
steps.description: Add 12 Cipollini onions that have been peeled and had their roots trimmed, ½ cup (21 g) of coarsely chopped fresh basil, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, and 1 teaspoon (5 g) of seasoned salt to a large bowl. Use a wooden spoon to stir the ingredients, so the onions are fully coated with the oil, herbs, and seasonings. If you prefer, you can season the onions with regular salt and pepper in place of the seasoned salt.

steps.headline: Chill the mixture for at least a half hour.
steps.description: After you've tossed the onions in the oil, herb, and seasoning mixture, cover the bowl with plastic wrap. Place it in the refrigerator and allow it to chill for 30 to 60 minutes so the flavors have time to meld.

steps.headline: Preheat your grill and oil the grate.
steps.description: When you're ready to grill the onions, turn on your grill and set the temperature to medium-high to preheat it. Next, dip a piece of paper towel into some olive oil and use a pair of tongs to wipe it over the grill grate to prevent the onions from sticking once you add them.

steps.headline: Place the onions and basil on the skewers.
steps.description: When the wooden skewers are finished soaking, remove them from the water. Thread the onions onto the skewers, placing pieces of the basil between them.

steps.headline: Cook the onion skewers on the grill for about 10 minutes.
steps.description: Set the skewered onions on the preheated grill. Allow them to cook until they are caramelized and tender, which should take about 10 minutes. Halfway through the grilling, turn the onions over to make sure that they cook evenly.

steps.headline: Serve the onions alongside your favorite grilled meat.
steps.description: When the onions are finished cooking, use tongs to remove them from the grill. Place them on a platter, and serve alongside some grilled meat while they're still warm.

text: Making Roasted Cipollini Onions Preheat the oven and place the rack in the center. To ensure that the oven is hot enough to roast the onions, set the temperature to 325°F (165°C) and allow it to fully heat. Make sure that the oven rack is the center position as well. Melt the butter on the stove. Add 4 tablespoons (57 g) of unsalted butter to a large non-stick skillet. Heat the butter over medium until it melts completely, which should take about 3 minutes. Toss the onions with the butter. Once the butter is melted, add 2 pounds (907 g) of cipollini onions that have been peeled and had their roots trimmed. Use a wooden spoon to stir the onions well so they're fully coated with the butter. Season the onions with salt and pepper. When the onions are coated with the butter, add some kosher salt and freshly ground pepper to taste. Stir well to ensure that the onions are evenly seasoned. Transfer the mixture to a roasting pan. After you've seasoned the onions, remove the skillet from the heat. Spoon the onions and melted butter into a roasting pan, making sure that they're evenly distributed and in a single layer. Cook the onions until tender. Place the onions in the preheated oven. Allow the onions to roast until they tender and fully caramelized, which should take about half an hour. While the onions are roasting, toss them occasionally to ensure that they cook evenly. Serve the onions immediately. When the onions are deeply caramelized, remove the pan from the oven. Transfer them to a platter and serve while they're still warm. Roasted cipollini onions are ideal side for any roasted meat main dish. Making Sautéed Cipollini Onions Heat the olive oil in a skillet. Add 3 tablespoons (45 ml) of olive oil to a large skillet. Allow the oil to heat on medium-high for 3 to 5 minutes, or until it begins to shimmer. Add the onions and season with salt. When the oil is heated, mix 2 pounds (907 g) of cipollini onions that have been peeled and had their roots trimmed into the pan. Stir in some salt to taste to season the onions. Sprinkle the onions with sugar and cook them for a minute. After you've seasoned the onions, scatter 1 tablespoon (12 ½ g) of sugar over them. Next, allow the onions to cook for 1 minute without stirring them. Mix in the butter and cook the onions until they begin to caramelize. When the onions have cooked for a minute, add 3 tablespoons (43 g) of butter to the pan and stir it in to help it melt. Continue cooking the onions until they begin to develop a deep caramelization, which should take about 5 to 10 minutes. Turn the onions over and mix in the thyme and sherry. When the onions are starting to caramelize, use a spatula to carefully turn them over. Cook them for another minute, and then add ¼ cup (10 g) of fresh thyme leaves and ⅓ cup (79 g) of sherry to the pan. Stir well to ensure that the ingredients are fully mixed. Allow the onions to cook for another 10 minutes. Once the thyme and sherry are mixed into the pan, let the onions cook for 10 more minutes. You'll know that they're done when they are tender and deeply caramelized all over. Remove the onions from the heat and stir in the cream. When the onions are finished sauteing, take the pan off the stove. Add ¼ cup (59 ml) of heavy cream to the pan, and mix it in well. If you like, you can also mix ¼ cup (30 g) of Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese into the pan. Season the onions and serve immediately. Once the cream is mixed into the onions, add as much salt and pepper to taste as you'd like. Transfer the onions to a dish and serve while they're still hot. Sautéed Cipollini onions pair well with roasted turkey. Making Grilled Cipollini Onions Soak some wooden skewers in water. To grill the onions, you'll need 2 to 4 wooden skewers, depending on how long they are. Place the skewers in a shallow dish and cover them with water. Let them soak for 30 minutes so they won't burn on the grill. Toss the onions, basil, salt, and oil together. Add 12 Cipollini onions that have been peeled and had their roots trimmed, ½ cup (21 g) of coarsely chopped fresh basil, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of olive oil, and 1 teaspoon (5 g) of seasoned salt to a large bowl. Use a wooden spoon to stir the ingredients, so the onions are fully coated with the oil, herbs, and seasonings. If you prefer, you can season the onions with regular salt and pepper in place of the seasoned salt. Chill the mixture for at least a half hour. After you've tossed the onions in the oil, herb, and seasoning mixture, cover the bowl with plastic wrap. Place it in the refrigerator and allow it to chill for 30 to 60 minutes so the flavors have time to meld. Preheat your grill and oil the grate. When you're ready to grill the onions, turn on your grill and set the temperature to medium-high to preheat it. Next, dip a piece of paper towel into some olive oil and use a pair of tongs to wipe it over the grill grate to prevent the onions from sticking once you add them. Place the onions and basil on the skewers. When the wooden skewers are finished soaking, remove them from the water. Thread the onions onto the skewers, placing pieces of the basil between them. Cook the onion skewers on the grill for about 10 minutes. Set the skewered onions on the preheated grill. Allow them to cook until they are caramelized and tender, which should take about 10 minutes. Halfway through the grilling, turn the onions over to make sure that they cook evenly. Serve the onions alongside your favorite grilled meat. When the onions are finished cooking, use tongs to remove them from the grill. Place them on a platter, and serve alongside some grilled meat while they're still warm.
